title: Case 01 | Force fades at boundary: from guessing to falsification
marketContext: Late range near upper boundary; liquidity dense above the boundary.
forceNote: Impulses shorten, pullbacks deepen, repeated failed attempts.
locationNote: Expression is only allowed near the boundary; avoid the middle.
falsificationNote: If price breaks and holds above the boundary (valid retest), exit the reversal narrative.
commonMistake: Reverse on one big candle without sequence confirmation.
homework: Write a three-sentence trade and fill an execution gate.

title: Case 02 | Breakout retest fails: the cost of chasing
marketContext: Mid-trend breakout; retest falls back into structure.
forceNote: Breakout force is mediocre; retest lacks support.
locationNote: Mid-trend breakouts fail more; wait for retest evidence.
falsificationNote: If retest fails and price returns inside structure, breakout is falsified.
commonMistake: Treat breakout as confirmation without retest falsification.
homework: Write three evidences for a valid retest and define the failure trigger.

title: Case 03 | Pullback continuation: trade quality, not pullback
marketContext: Pullback into a key support in trend.
forceNote: Pullback is orderly; no panic selling.
locationNote: Support is the expression window; break = exit.
falsificationNote: If support breaks and retest fails, continuation is invalid.
commonMistake: Scale in during pullback without reading its quality.
homework: Score impulse and pullback with a force scorecard.

title: Case 04 | Failure sequences: sequences over pattern names
marketContext: Repeated failed pushes at a key level.
forceNote: Impulse quality deteriorates; pullbacks deepen.
locationNote: Near boundary—observe reversal sequences.
falsificationNote: If new highs establish and hold, the failure narrative breaks.
commonMistake: Treat one wick as a 'stop hunt completed'.
homework: Write a 3-step reversal confirmation sequence and a delay rule.

title: Case 05 | Trading the middle: why stops get hit
marketContext: Range middle with weak boundaries and random swings.
forceNote: Alternating impulses and pullbacks without edge.
locationNote: Middle belongs on the no-trade list.
falsificationNote: No boundary + no falsification = fail by default.
commonMistake: Treat random swings as opportunities without location filters.
homework: Add 'middle-of-range' to your gate fail rules.

title: Case 06 | Wicks are attempts: failure vs success
marketContext: Long wicks appear near a key level.
forceNote: Wicks indicate attempts absorbed or rejected; confirm via follow-through.
locationNote: Wicks matter more at boundaries than in the middle.
falsificationNote: If price continues and holds, the wick-failure story is falsified.
commonMistake: Treat wicks as guaranteed reversals.
homework: Collect 10 wick cases and write falsification for each.

title: Case 07 | Reversal delay rule: express after second confirmation
marketContext: Late trend enters a transition regime.
forceNote: Reversal impulse appears but needs confirmation.
locationNote: Near boundary—wait for second test.
falsificationNote: If reversal fails and price returns to the old structure, exit.
commonMistake: Reverse heavy on the first counter candle.
homework: Write 'failed second test' as your entry condition.

title: Case 08 | Clean breakout: express after valid retest
marketContext: Breakout followed by a strong retest hold.
forceNote: Support is clear during retest; continuation holds.
locationNote: Express after retest holds—never at the breakout moment.
falsificationNote: If retest fails and price returns inside, exit.
commonMistake: Chase the breakout and get swept on retest.
homework: Write three evidences for a valid retest: location, force, structure.

title: Case 09 | High volatility: fixed parameters get washed out
marketContext: High-vol assets expand ranges under events.
forceNote: Both impulses and pullbacks widen; noise increases.
locationNote: Location still matters, but stops and size must adapt.
falsificationNote: Falsification stays structural; parameters adapt to volatility.
commonMistake: Use low-vol parameters in high-vol markets.
homework: Write one parameter adjustment rule for high-vol conditions.

title: Case 10 | Force scoring: replace subjective words
marketContext: Trend alternates between impulse and pullback.
forceNote: High impulse score, low pullback score—advantage is visible.
locationNote: Express near the boundary after pullback ends.
falsificationNote: If boundary breaks and fails to reclaim, exit.
commonMistake: Use 'feels strong/weak' instead of reviewable metrics.
homework: Score your last 20 trades and check correlation with outcomes.

title: Case 11 | Timeframe conflicts: the best trade is passing
marketContext: HTF boundary holds while LTF shows reversal signals.
forceNote: LTF reversal exists but HTF constraints remain.
locationNote: In conflict, risk increases—size down or pass.
falsificationNote: If conflict isn’t resolved, fail by default.
commonMistake: Bet heavy in conflicts and rely on stop-outs.
homework: Write a conflict rule: size down / pass / delay.

title: Case 12 | No falsification: you’re gambling
marketContext: Entry is a vague feeling without boundary language.
forceNote: Force and structure reasoning is incomplete.
locationNote: Location is unclear; risk frame is missing.
falsificationNote: No falsification sentence = gate fail.
commonMistake: Treat stop price as falsification; falsification is a failed narrative.
homework: Rewrite the trade using Force/Location/Falsification.

title: Case 13 | Pullback or transition: use sequences
marketContext: Trend pullback deepens and looks like transition.
forceNote: Impulses fail; pullback breaks key structure.
locationNote: After boundary loss, wait for a second test.
falsificationNote: If price re-enters trend structure and holds, transition breaks.
commonMistake: Reverse early on one deep pullback.
homework: Write a 3-step sequence to separate pullback vs transition.

title: Case 14 | Accumulation/distribution: a falsifiable narrative
marketContext: Range with repeated tests on both edges.
forceNote: No continuation; repeated failed/successful attempts at boundaries.
locationNote: Edges are the only meaningful locations; avoid the middle.
falsificationNote: If breakout holds with valid retest, switch to trend logic.
commonMistake: Treat it as mysticism without falsification.
homework: Write a clear falsification sentence for your narrative.

title: Case 15 | Exit delay: turn falsification into action
marketContext: Falsification triggers but execution is delayed—loss expands.
forceNote: Failure signals are clear, but action is late.
locationNote: After boundary loss, exit immediately.
falsificationNote: Trigger → exit. Do not debate 'it might come back'.
commonMistake: Treat exits as ego failure.
homework: Measure delay from trigger to execution across 20 trades.

title: Case 16 | Daily risk cap: a stability boundary
marketContext: High-noise days increase impulses.
forceNote: Signal noise rises under instability.
locationNote: Stay selective; reduce frequency and size.
falsificationNote: After daily risk cap triggers, every trade idea is invalid.
commonMistake: Double down after daily losses and break hard limits.
homework: Write daily risk caps into your gate and tools.

title: Case 17 | Multi-asset: one framework across markets
marketContext: FX/Gold/Indices/Crypto differ in volatility and structure.
forceNote: Impulse and pullback ranges differ widely.
locationNote: Boundaries remain core; parameters must adapt.
falsificationNote: Keep the same structure: failure condition + exit action.
commonMistake: Use identical parameters and narratives across assets.
homework: Write four markets with one template using the method.

title: Case 18 | Chop: write 'no edge' into no-trade rules
marketContext: Range middle with heavy noise.
forceNote: Short impulses with quick failures.
locationNote: Express near edges only.
falsificationNote: No boundary + no falsification = pass.
commonMistake: Frequent probing leads to accumulated losses.
homework: Write 5 no-trade rules for chop.

title: Case 19 | Trend continuation: evidence after pullback
marketContext: Trend pulls back to a key level and continues.
forceNote: After pullback, impulse quality returns.
locationNote: Key level defines risk boundary.
falsificationNote: If key level breaks and retest fails, exit.
commonMistake: Enter too early during pullback without confirmation.
homework: Define 3 confirmation conditions for pullback end.

title: Case 20 | FOMO chasing: lock impulse outside the gate
marketContext: Fast move triggers chase impulses.
forceNote: Strong force doesn’t guarantee valid location.
locationNote: Chasing in the middle is high risk; wait for retest/pullback.
falsificationNote: No clear boundary = fail.
commonMistake: Treat speed as edge; ignore location and falsification.
homework: Write a 3-minute delay rule for chase impulses.

title: Case 21 | Revenge trades: the second mistake
marketContext: After a loss, the urge to reverse and size up appears.
forceNote: At this moment you trade emotion cost, not evidence.
locationNote: Location filters get overridden by feelings.
falsificationNote: If cooldown protocol triggers, expression is forbidden.
commonMistake: Make 'winning back' the goal and break the system.
homework: Write one hard limit: forced stop after revenge impulses.

title: Case 22 | Scorecard trends: consistency over single outcomes
marketContext: Outcomes vary; score trends reflect stability.
forceNote: Avoid outcome-based stories; return to execution quality.
locationNote: Only judge whether you expressed at boundaries.
falsificationNote: If scores decline over time, rules drift—rebuild the gate.
commonMistake: Only track PnL and ignore violations.
homework: Score 10 trades and identify the weakest dimension.

title: Case 23 | Falsification triggers: exit
marketContext: Falsification triggers but you wait for recovery.
forceNote: Advantage is gone while waiting.
locationNote: Boundary loss means narrative failure.
falsificationNote: Trigger → exit, then review.
commonMistake: Treat exits as right/wrong rather than probability management.
homework: Write a hard rule: no averaging down after falsification.

title: Case 24 | Weekly prescription: convert errors into actions
marketContext: Same errors repeat weekly.
forceNote: Mistakes often come from unclear boundaries and execution drift.
locationNote: Trades cluster in low-edge locations.
falsificationNote: If you can’t write falsification and gate rules, the prescription is invalid.
commonMistake: Summarize but don’t design next-week actions.
homework: Publish a weekly review: top violations + 3 actions + no-trade zones.
